messageBody:
Pankaj Solanki wrote:
>
> Thanks Shane,
> I will try that.
> Will you please tell me how to create JUnit library and its inclusion in the
> project.

What I do in JBuilder4, is create two projects, one that has the source
for the
app and one that has the source for the test files and refers to the
sources in
the first project.

In the test project, I select the menu Project -> Project Properties...
and
under the "Required Libraries" tab I pick the "Add..." button and
navigate
to the JUnit project and select the junit.jar file. Now, I've done this
a
bunch of times and JUnit is there to select as a library. The first time
you
do this, you may have to pick "Add..." and then click on the "New...",
fill
out the form and click on the "Add" button to select the junit.jar file
for
the library path.

As others have noted, you then run the test by selecting the menu for
Project -> Project Properties, and then click on the Run tab. Under the
application tab, you'll see text that says "Main Class:" and a "..."
button.
Click on the "..." button and select one of the JUnit TestRunner entries
under Junit (for example - junit -> swingui -> TestRunner). Then under
the "Application Parameters" field enter in the fully qualified name to
your class that contains the top level test suite (or the test or suite
you want to run). For example, I just did
jdepend.framework.JDependTestSuite
for the JDepend program that Mike Clark publishes (www.clarkware.com).

Under the "VM parameters" field, you may want to enter "-classic". I
found
out from some kind sole, after some frustrating runs, that without this
flag running under debug, breakpoints would only be "seen" the first
time
they are encountered. So if you had a break in a method that was called
10
times, you'd only see the debugger break the first time you hit that
breakpoint.
Turning on the "classic" options allows this to work as expected. I
think,
and I may be wrong, that it was something with JIT or some optimization
that
1.3 had and it causes problems with JBuilder. The "classic" option puts
it
in 1.2 mode, from what I gather.

Hope that helps...and that I didn't forget anything!
